ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: It completely changed the way I view lyric writing as an art form (that is also sort of a science)

I gained a much better understanding of the types of songs in a musical, the subtle differences between styles (eg. the rules in opera versus a musical), and I got practice at collaborating with a composer.
I learned how to write effective lyrics, both given music and written without music.
This was a great class! I learned the foundations of lyric writing, including finding a hook, musical theatre structure, and how to make a story flow through song.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is amazing! Professor Korie has great, direct feedback and brought in amazing guests that had a ton to offer for anyone interested in the theater industry, not just lyric writing.

I liked the low pressure regarding grades. Professor Korie really pushed the class to improve, but did not threaten our grades. This helped me completely focus on the skill instead of just maintaining the grade in the class.

Strengths: lots of exposure to musical theatre, great opportunities to work with others, lots of chances to write and produce a lot of work!

Weaknesses: If you're looking for a lot of structure, this is probably not the course for you. Assignments are done independently and you're never required to share your work, so you definitely get out of this class what you put into it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Take it if youre interested in lyrics for musical theater, but also in songwriting more broadly or theater in general. As someone looking to direct and produce, getting to try the creative aspect of collaboration firsthand was not only incredibly fun, but I am certain it has made me a stronger collaborator since I will have a better understanding of what my creative colleagues need to be supported in their process.
Yes, I would absolutely recommend this class to another student. It is a great way to get to work with other creative students and hone a skill that you may not have tried without this class.

Heres the deal. Lyric writing is an easy A as long as you do the work. However, because the course doesnt have a lot of minor assignments or tangible expectations from you, its easy to skate by and not actually take away anything. If youre actually interested in the craft of lyric writing, make sure youre always working on something because unlike Musical Theater Composition, there is no write a song a week requirement, and otherwise, youll leave the semester going, did I even write anything?. Im glad I took the course as a TAPS major who has a particular interest in writing musical theater, but if youre not actually interested in the topic and are just looking for the easy A, youll probably find it, but youll be bored. If youre passionate about writing musical theatre and the grade isnt the reason youre taking the class, it can be a bit disheartening when Korie criticizes your work harshly, but its also useful exposure to harsh criticism that doesnt actually reflect in your grade, which I found refreshing. Rarely when a professor says they dont believe in grading creativity do they actually follow through, but I give Korie credit- he actually grades purely on participation and his critiques are purely for your own self-edification.

Definitely! If you're interesting in song-writing, musical theatre or otherwise, this is a great class to introduce you to the basics, give you opportunities to write, and expose you to other students who have similar interests.
